title: Algorithms & Abstract Data Types
prereq: CMPS(12B or 13H), CMPE(16 or 16H), Math( 11B or 19B or 20B) & Math(21, 22, 23A) or AMS(10)
info: Studies basic algorithms and their relationships to common abstract data types. Covers the notions of abstract data types and the distinction between an abstract data type and an implementation of that data type.

title: Computational Methods
info: Various representations for regular languages, context-free grammars, normal forms, parsing, pushdown automata, pumping lemmas, Turing machines, the Church-Turing thesis.

title: Comparative Programming Languages
info: Covers several programming languages and compares styles, philosophy, and design principles. Principles underlying declarative, functional, and object-oriented programming styles are studied.

title: Intro to Programming(Aceelerated)/ Lab
info: Topics include: functions; conditionals and loops; classes; event-driven programming and graphic user interfaces (GUIs); recursion; and arrays.
prereq: Math(3 or 11A or 19A) or AMS(3 or 11A)

title: Compiler Design 1
info: Topics include compiler structure, symbol tables, regular expressions and languages, finite automata, lexical analysis, context-free languages, LL(1), recursive descent, LALR(1), and LR(1) parsing

title: Intro to Data Structures
info: Teaches students to implement common data structures and the algorithms associated with each data structure, through progressively difficult exercises.

title: Intro to Operating Systems
info: Process synchronization, deadlocks, memory management, resource allocation, scheduling, storage systems, and study of several operating systems.

title: Intro. to Analysis of Algorithms
info: Methods for the systematic construction and mathematical analysis of algorithms. Order notation, the RAM model of computation, lower bounds, and recurrence relations are covered.

title: Computer Systems and C Programming
info: You will learn how to program in C, how to write modular code, and some of the tips and tricks when dealing with an embedded micro.

title: Honors Introduction to Programming and Data Structures
info: This course presents an honors-level introduction to programming and data structures including the fundamentals of java programming and basic data structures such as linked lists, queues, trees, hashing, and computational complexity.

title: Introduction to Programming in Java
info: This course introduces programming in Java for students who have no prior programming experience. Students learn programming and documentation skills, as well as algorithmic problem-solving, and programming methodologies

title: Intermediate Programming
info: Covers basic object-oriented programming, event-driven programming, graphical user interface (GUI) creation, recursion, two-dimensional arrays
prereq: 5J, Math(3 or 11A or 19A) or AMS(3 or 11A)

title: Intro. Software Engineering
info: Emphasizes the characteristics of well-engineered software systems. Topics include requirements analysis and specification, design, programming, verification and validation, maintenance, and project management.

title: Computability and Computational Complexity
info: Computational complexity, time and space bounds, NP-completeness with emphasis on reductions between problems from various areas.

title: Database Systems
info: Concepts, approaches, tools, and methodology of database design

title: Technical Writing
info: Writing and communication by computer science professionals to a technical audience

title: Senior Thesis Research
info: senior thesis consists of a self-contained project within the broad scope of computer science, but one that is not available in the regular course offerings
prereq: The student first submits a written thesis proposal and obtains approval of a faculty sponsor.

title: Intro. Data Visualization & Lab
info: Concepts and methods for data analysis, information and scientific visualization, and effective communication of technical data

title: Database System II
info: Introduction to the architecture and implementation of database systems. Topics covered include data storage, tree and hash indexes, storage management, query evaluation and optimization, transaction management, concurrency control, recovery, and XML data management.

title: Fundamentals of Compiler Design II
info: Topics include compiler structure emphasizing the back end, type systems, run-time environments; static, stack and heap storage management, garbage collection; addressing, register allocation, code generation; basic blocks and data-flow analysis; local and global code optimization; interpretation versus compilation.

title: Software Design Project II
info: Continuation of course 116. Students work in teams to develop, test, document, and deploy a substantial software project. Teams give a formal presentation and demonstration of each project.

title: Intro Physics I
info: Elementary mechanics. Vectors, Newton's laws, inverse square force laws, work and energy, conservation of momentum and energy, and oscillations.

title: Kinematics
info: Elementary mechanics. Vectors, Newton's laws, inverse square force laws, work and energy, conservation of momentum and energy, and oscillations.

title: Intro Physics II
info: Geometric optics; statics and dynamics of fluids; introduction to thermodynamics, including temperature, heat, thermal conductivity, and molecular motion; wave motion in matter, including sound waves.

title: Intro.Physics II
info: Geometric optics; statics and dynamics of fluids; introduction to thermodynamics, including temperature, heat, thermal conductivity, and molecular motion; wave motion in matter, including sound waves.

title: Intro. Physics III
info: Introduction to electricity and magnetism. Electromagnetic radiation, Maxwell's equations.

title: Intro. Physics III
info: Introduction to electricity and magnetism. Electromagnetic radiation, Maxwell's equations.

title: General Chemistry I
info: Covers a range of topics including the atomic structure of matter; molecules; chemical reactions; acids and bases; gases; and equilibria in the gas and liquid phase. Students expected to use algebra to solve problems.

title: General Chemistry II
info: Coverage includes quantum mechanics; the hydrogen atom; many-electron atoms and chemical periodicity; elementary covalent bonding; transition metals; and chemical kinetics.

title: General Chemistry III
info: Coverage includes thermodynamics; oxidation-reduction and electrochemistry; liquids and solids; intermolecular forces and solutions, including colligative properties; and nuclear chemistry.

title: Applied Discrete Math
info: Topics include sets, functions, relations, graphs, trees, switching algebra, first order predicate calculus, mathematical induction, permutations, combinations, summation, and recurrences.
prereq: Math(11A or 19A or 20A)or AMS( 11B or 15B) or ECON 11B

title: Probability And Statistics For Engineers
info: Probability, conditional probability, Bayes Theorem, random variables, independence, Poisson processes, Bernnoulli trials, and Markov chains.

title: Computer Architecture
info: Computer performance evaluation, basic combinatorial and sequential digital components, different instruction set architectures with a focus on the MIPS ISA and RISC paradigm.

title: Comp. Sys. and Assembly Lang.
info: Topics include digital logic, number systems, data structures, compiling/assembly process, basics of system software, and computer architecture.

title: Intro. To Probability Theory
info: Combinatorial analysis, axioms of probability and independence, random variables (discrete and continuous), joint probability distributions, properties of expectation, Central Limit Theorem, Law of Large Numbers, Markov chains.
prereq: AMS(11B) or ECON(11B) or Math(11B or 19B)

title: Mathematical Methods For Engineers I.
info: Vectors, bases, and transformations; matrix algebra; solutions of linear systems, inverses and determinants; eigenvalues and eigenvectors; and geometric transformations.

title: Numerical Analysis
info: Topics are difference equations, linear algebra, iteration, Bernoulli's method, quotient difference algorithm, the interpolating polynomial, numerical differentiation and integration, numerical solution of differential equations, finite Fourier series
prereq: Math(22 or 23A), (21 and 24) or AMS(10, 20), (100) or CMPS(101)

title: Math Control Theory
info: Theory behind control systems

title: Graph Theory
info: Graph theory, trees, vertex and edge colorings, Hamilton cycles, Eulerian circuits, decompositions into isomorphic subgraphs, extremal problems, cages, Ramsey theory, Cayley's spanning tree formula, planar graphs, Euler's formula, crossing numbers, thickness, splitting numbers, magic graphs, graceful trees, rotations, and genus of graphs.
prereq: Math(21) or AMS(10) and  Math(100) or CMPS(101)

title: Comp. Methods and App.
info: Topics include solution of nonlinear equations, linear systems, differential equations, sparse matrix solver, and eigenvalue problems.

title: Introduction To Financial Mathematics.
info: Financial derivatives: contracts and options. Hedging and risk managment. Arbitrage, interest rate, and discounted value. Geometric random walk and Brownian motion as models of risky assets. Ito's formula

title: Vector Calculus
info: Vectors in n-dimensional Euclidean space. The inner and cross products. The derivative of functions from n-dimensional to m-dimensional Euclidean space is studied as a linear transformation having matrix representation.

title: Honors Calculus
info: Challenging course designed to approach single-variable calculus from the perspective of modern mathematics. Emphasis is on the evolution and historical development of core concepts underlying calculus and analysis.

title: Honors Calculus
info: Challenging course designed to approach single-variable calculus from the perspective of modern mathematics. Emphasis is on the evolution and historical development of core concepts underlying calculus and analysis.
prereq: AP Calc. AB score of 4 or 5, MP score >499

title: Calculus for Science, Engineering and Mathematics.
info: The definite integral and the fundamental theorem of calculus. Areas, volumes. Integration by parts, trigonometric substitution, and partial fractions methods. Improper integrals. Sequences, series, absolute convergence and convergence tests. Power series, Taylor and Maclaurin series.

title: Calculus for Science, Engineering and Mathematics.
info: The limit of a function, calculating limits, continuity, tangents, velocities, and other instantaneous rates of change. Derivatives, the chain rule, implicit differentiation, higher derivatives. Exponential functions, inverse functions, and their derivatives.
